dialogue: Look at the top bar showing three-sixths. Shade the bottom bar to show the same amount.
prompt: Create a fraction equivalent to three-sixths.

workspace.description: Empty fraction strip divided into fourths

correct_answer.context: Shading 2 out of 4 parts creates 2/4, which equals 3/6 (both equal to one-half)

success_path_dialogue: Good. You shaded two out of four equal parts.

steps.dialogue: Not quite. Look at how much of the top bar is shaded, then shade the same amount on the bottom bar.

Let's think about this together. The top bar has 3 out of 6 parts shaded - that's half of the bar. Now look at the bottom bar with 4 parts. How many of those 4 parts would equal half? Shade that many parts.

Let me walk you through this. First, let's see what fraction the top bar shows. It has 3 out of 6 parts shaded, which is 3/6. Notice that 3/6 equals half of the whole bar. Now for the bottom bar - it's divided into 4 equal parts. To show the same amount as the top bar, we need to shade half of this bar too. Half of 4 parts is 2 parts. So we shade 2 out of the 4 parts to make 2/4. Both 3/6 and 2/4 equal one-half. That's how equivalent fractions work - they show the same amount even with different denominators.
